intro: Castilleja purpurea var. citrina, commonly known as the yellow milkvetch, is a hemiparasitic flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its yellow to orange flowers and slender, branched stems. The plant lacks true leaves, relying on its roots to parasitize the roots of other plants for nutrients. It thrives in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. Its unique ecological role makes it an important species in certain ecosystems.
